bibl.title: Letter from Walter Lawrence Reed to Albert E. Truby, September 11, 1943

div1.p: Lawrence Reed praises Truby's book on Walter Reed. He vividly remembers Truby's efforts to eradicate mosquito breeding sites.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Lawrence Reed to Albert E. Truby, September 11, 1943
div1.opener:
Copy
W A R D E P A R T M E N T
Washington, D. C.
11 September 1943.
My dear Truby -
div1.p:
A few days ago Dick LeGarde presented me with your
memoirs of Father and his work in Cuba, inscribed by both yourself
and Dick. I have delayed writing until I had finished reading it.

I can't tell you how highly I prize this work of
yours because I have always known that few if any persons had the
intimate knowledge of Father's work that you had and few knew him
more intimately.

To my mind you have portrayed his character and
scientific accomplishments beautifully, and it was with deep in-
terest that I read and reread your book.

It has been many years since you and I were at
Rowell Barracks, but I have the most vivid recollection of your
interest in unearthing the many mosquito breeding places (bottle
borders on all walks) that were on hand when you took over the
job of cleaning up the mosquito situation.

I trust you and your family are still enjoying the
best of health and good old California.

Mrs. Reed joins me in again thanking you for your
book and in kindest regards to you both.
div1.closer:
I am as ever most affectionately, Sig - LAWRENCE Letter from
Major General Walter Lawrence Reed.
A.E.T.
